title: 114_hr5212
content: The Act may be cited as the "Bereaved Consumer's Bill of Rights Act of 2016". Congress finds shocking consumer abuses in the funeral industry, high expenses for funeral arrangements, the importance of preneed arrangements, vulnerability of grieving family members during funeral planning, and limitations of the Funeral Rule in protecting consumers. The funeral industry faces consumer abuses, high costs, and the need for better protections. State laws are inconsistent and weak, requiring minimum Federal standards. Consumers deserve clear information, protection from fraud, and new Federal laws to safeguard grieving families. The FTC will create rules to prevent unfair or deceptive practices in the funeral industry. The Federal Trade Commission will establish rules to prohibit unfair or deceptive practices in the funeral industry, including requirements for accurate price information, prohibition of misrepresentations, and restrictions on conditioning the purchase of funeral goods or services. The Federal Trade Commission will establish rules to prohibit unfair or deceptive practices in the funeral industry, including requirements for accurate price information, prohibition of misrepresentations, and restrictions on conditioning the purchase of funeral goods or services. These rules include clear and written presale disclosures and contracts for funeral services or goods, disclosure of penalties for canceling prepaid contracts, and clear disclosure of all future fees and costs for funeral services or goods. Cemeteries are also required to provide consumers with necessary information. (7) Cemeteries must provide consumers with written rules, regulations, and clear explanations of purchased interment rights. (8) Cemeteries must retain records of all interments and accurately record all related information. The Commission shall prescribe rules within 1 year after the enactment of the Act for the sale of internment, inurnment, or entombment rights. Records must be made available to government entities. Rules apply to tax-exempt organizations and states. The rules prohibiting unfair or deceptive acts in the funeral industry also apply to certain tax-exempt cemeteries, except those affiliated with for-profit providers. The Act prohibits unfair or deceptive acts related to goods or services for sale to the public or by States. Violations will be treated as violations of the Federal Trade Commission Act, with enforcement by the FTC. Penalties and immunities will apply to violators. The Act prohibits unfair or deceptive acts related to goods or services for sale to the public or by States, with enforcement by the FTC. Penalties and immunities will apply to violators. Additionally, enforcement by States is authorized under Section 4. Whenever an attorney general of a State believes that residents are affected by a violation of FTC rules, the State can bring a civil action in federal court to stop the violation, enforce compliance, seek damages, or obtain other relief. The State must notify the FTC before taking legal action. The State can bring a civil action to the Commission under subsection (a) or (f)(2), providing a copy of the complaint. The Commission has the right to intervene, be heard on all matters, remove the action to federal court, and file petitions for appeal. The attorney general can still conduct investigations or administer oaths for civil actions under subsection (a). The State can bring a civil action to the Commission under subsection (a) or (f)(2), providing a copy of the complaint. The Commission has the right to intervene, be heard on all matters, remove the action to federal court, and file petitions for appeal. The attorney general can still conduct investigations or administer oaths for civil actions under subsection (a). In addition, no State may institute a civil action under subsection (a) or (f)(2) against a defendant named in a complaint filed by the Commission for violation of any rule during the pendency of the Commission's action. Any civil action brought under subsection (a) in a district court of the United States may be brought in the district where the defendant is found, is an inhabitant, or transacts business, or wherever venue is proper under section 1391 of title 28, United States Code. Section 1391 of title 28, United States Code allows for process serving in any district where the defendant is located. Authorized State officials can proceed in State court for violations of State statutes. Officers authorized by the State can also bring actions on behalf of residents. SEC. 5. EFFECT ON OTHER LAW. This Act does not override any State laws protecting consumers of funeral services, except where there is inconsistency. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. The term "cemetery" refers to organizations offering interment services, excluding those with fewer than 25 interments or sales per year. "Funeral goods" are items sold for funeral services, and "funeral services" include any services sold to the public for funerals. The curr_chunk discusses services provided by funeral directors, morticians, cemeterians, cremationists, and retailers of funeral-related products.
